paragraphs.text: %md
%md

%md

# Alpenglow Alpenglow is a free and open source C++ based Python recommender framework. We use it train a matrix factorization model using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and evaluate the trained model using the normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG) metric. This experiment is impemented in Python

msg.data:
Alpenglow

Alpenglow is a free and open source C++ based Python recommender framework. We use it train a matrix factorization model using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and evaluate the trained model using the normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG) metric.

This experiment is impemented in Python

paragraphs.title: Flink
paragraphs.text:
%md

# Apache Flink Flink is an open-source stream processing framework. We use a factor model trained by asynchronous SGD, available as a pull request for Flink. The implementation uses a paramtere-server architecture for storing and accessing the model. This experiment is implemented in Scala.

msg.data:
Apache Flink

Flink is an open-source stream processing framework. We use a factor model trained by asynchronous SGD, available as a pull request for Flink. The implementation uses a paramtere-server architecture for storing and accessing the model.

This experiment is implemented in Scala.

paragraphs.title: Spark
paragraphs.text:
%md

# Apache Spark Spark is an open-source engine for large-scale data processing. We use the iALS implementation from Spark’s ML library, and provide ranking recommendations by reading the trained factor model to pandas. The experiment is implemented in Spark’s Python API, PySpark.

msg.data:
Apache Spark

Spark is an open-source engine for large-scale data processing. We use the iALS implementation from Spark’s ML library, and provide ranking recommendations by reading the trained factor model to pandas.

The experiment is implemented in Spark’s Python API, PySpark.

paragraphs.text:
%md 

### Warning!

Running all three kernels simultaneously requires quite a bit of system memory.

* If you have at least 16GB, you should be good to go.
* With 8GB, you should still be fine, but monitor your memory usage closely.
* Under 8GB, you can try running the notebook one kernel at a time. This can be achieved by restarting the unused kernels in the *interpreter binding* menu (upper right corner, gear button). Make sure to run the evalutaion paragraph last!

paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import alpenglow as ag
from alpenglow.offline.models import FactorModel
from alpenglow.offline.evaluation import NdcgScore

%flink

import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.Utils._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.data.parsers._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.PSOfflineMatrixFactorization._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.sinks._
import hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.PSTopKGeneratorWithLEMPForTutorial._

senv.setParallelism(4)

%spark.pyspark

from pyspark.mllib.recommendation import ALS, MatrixFactorizationModel, Rating
import pandas as pd
import shutil
import pyarrow.parquet as pq

paragraphs.title: reading data
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Reading the data

* In Python, we use Pandas to read the csv file into a dataframe.
* In Flink, we use the ImplicitDataParser class to read the file into a datastream of Rating objects.
* In Spark, we use Spark's textFile function to read the data as raw text, and parse the csv format into an RDD of Rating objects using maps.

msg.data:
Reading the data

  • In Python, we use Pandas to read the csv file into a dataframe.
  • In Flink, we use the ImplicitDataParser class to read the file into a datastream of Rating objects.
  • In Spark, we use Spark’s textFile function to read the data as raw text, and parse the csv format into an RDD of Rating objects using maps.

paragraphs.text:
%python

train_batch = pd.read_csv(
    'recsys-2017-tutorial/train_batch.csv',
    header=None,
    names=['time','user','item']
)

%flink

val trainFile = "recsys-2017-tutorial/train_batch.csv"
val modelFile = "flink_model"

val trainData = ImplicitDataToRatingParser.parse(senv,trainFile,",",1,2)

msg.data:
trainFile: String = recsys-2017-tutorial/train_batch.csv
modelFile: String = flink_model
trainData: hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.utils.DataStreamWithNameableFunctions[hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.matrix.factorization.Utils.Rating] = hu.sztaki.ilab.ps.utils.DataStreamWithNameableFunctions@511ae2c

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

train = sc.textFile("recsys-2017-tutorial/train_batch.csv")\
    .map(lambda l: l.split(','))\
    .map(lambda l: Rating(int(l[1]), int(l[2]), 1.0))

paragraphs.title: training models
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Training models

* Creating a factor model in Alpenglow is pretty straightforward. We set the number of latent dimensions is 10, the learning rate of the SGD process is 0.05 and we iterate over the data 4 times. To handle implicit data, we generate 9 negative samples after each positive sample.
* Flink's parameter server based offline matrix factorization model is set up similarly to Alpenglow's model. We need to add a sink to write the model to disk.
* In Spark we train the matrix factor model using a iALS instead of SGD; the parameters are thus somewhat different.

msg.data:
Training models

  • Creating a factor model in Alpenglow is pretty straightforward. We set the number of latent dimensions is 10, the learning rate of the SGD process is 0.05 and we iterate over the data 4 times. To handle implicit data, we generate 9 negative samples after each positive sample.
  • Flink’s parameter server based offline matrix factorization model is set up similarly to Alpenglow’s model. We need to add a sink to write the model to disk.
  • In Spark we train the matrix factor model using a iALS instead of SGD; the parameters are thus somewhat different.

paragraphs.text:
%python

model = FactorModel(
    dimension=20,
    learning_rate=0.05,
    negative_rate=9,
    number_of_iterations=4,
)
model.fit(train_batch)

%flink

psOfflineMF(
        trainData,
        learningRate = 0.05,
        negativeSampleRate = 9,
        iterations = 4)
    .addSink(new VectorModelToFileSink(modelFile))
    .setParallelism(1)

senv.execute()

%spark.pyspark

rank = 20
numIter = 8
reg = 0.01
alpha = 2

model = ALS.trainImplicit(train, rank, numIter, reg, alpha)

paragraphs.title: calculating toplists
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Calculating toplists

Alpenglow's and Flink's matrix factor model implementations provide utilities to compute top-k predictions using [LEMP algorithm](https://people.mpi-inf.mpg.de/~chteflio/publications/teflioudi15.pdf), which can speed up the recommendation process. To create toplists based on Spark's model, we read the factors into Pandas and calculate the toplists by brute-force.

msg.data:
Calculating toplists

Alpenglow’s and Flink’s matrix factor model implementations provide utilities to compute top-k predictions using LEMP algorithm, which can speed up the recommendation process. To create toplists based on Spark’s model, we read the factors into Pandas and calculate the toplists by brute-force.

paragraphs.text:
%python

train_test_users = pd.read_csv('recsys-2017-tutorial/train_test_users.csv', header=None)[0].values
alpenglow_topks = model.recommend(train_test_users, k=100)
alpenglow_topks.to_csv('alpenglow_topks.csv', index=False)

%flink

val users = senv.readTextFile("train_test_users.csv")
val usersForToplist = users.map((x:String) => Rating(x.toInt,0,0,0))
val modelStream = VectorModelFileParser.parse(senv, modelFile, numFactors = 10)

psTopKGenerator(
        usersForToplist,
        model = modelStream)
    .addSink(new TopKToFileSink("flink_topks.csv"))
    .setParallelism(1)

senv.execute()

paragraphs.text:
%spark.pyspark

# saving the model from spark

try:
    shutil.rmtree('spark_model')
except FileNotFoundError:
    pass
model.save(sc, "spark_model")

# loading the model to pandas dataframes

def read_factors(filename, colname):
    vectors = pq.read_table(filename).to_pandas()
    vectors.columns = [colname,'factors']
    vectors = pd.concat([ vectors[colname], vectors['factors'].apply(pd.Series) ], axis=1) 
    return vectors

user_vectors = read_factors("spark_model/data/user", "user")
item_vectors = read_factors("spark_model/data/product", "item")
item_vectors.set_index('item', inplace=True)

# preparing topk generation
train_test_users = pd.read_csv('recsys-2017-tutorial/train_test_users.csv', header=None)[0]
relevant_user_vectors = user_vectors[user_vectors.user.isin(train_test_users)]

#calculating the toplists using pandas

user_toplists = []

for v in relevant_user_vectors.values:
    user = v[0]
    user_vec = pd.Series(v[1:])
    items = item_vectors\
        .multiply(user_vec,axis=1)\
        .sum(axis=1)\
        .nlargest(100)\
        .index

    for item,rank in zip(items, range(1,101)):
    	user_toplists.append((user,item,rank))

#saving the toplists to csv, to be read by the python kernel

spark_topks = pd.DataFrame.from_records(user_toplists, columns=['user','item','rank'])
spark_topks.to_csv('spark_topks.csv', index=False)

%md

# Evaluating toplists using Alpenglow

When evaluating recommender systems, a standard ranking based metric is discounted cumulative gain @ K (DCG@K),
$$
\mathrm{DCG}@K =  \sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\mathrm{rel}(i_k)}{\log_2(1+k)}
$$
where rel(i_k) notes the relevance of the i-th item in the list. For the implicit task, the relevance is 1 if the user considered the item in the evaluation set, otherwise it is 0. This value is usually normalized using the highest achievable score, yielding the *normalized* discounted cumulative gain (NDCG).

For fair evaluation, we use Alpenglow's NDCG evaluator to evaluate all three systems.

msg.data:
Evaluating toplists using Alpenglow

When evaluating recommender systems, a standard ranking based metric is discounted cumulative gain @ K (DCG@K),
$$
\mathrm{DCG}@K = \sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\mathrm{rel}(i_k)}{\log_2(1+k)}
$$
where rel(i_k) notes the relevance of the i-th item in the list. For the implicit task, the relevance is 1 if the user considered the item in the evaluation set, otherwise it is 0. This value is usually normalized using the highest achievable score, yielding the normalized discounted cumulative gain (NDCG).

For fair evaluation, we use Alpenglow’s NDCG evaluator to evaluate all three systems.

paragraphs.title: evaluating toplists using Alpenglow
paragraphs.text:
%python

flink_topks = pd.read_csv('flink_topks.csv', header=None, names=['user','item','rank'])
spark_topks = pd.read_csv('spark_topks.csv')
alpenglow_topks = pd.read_csv('alpenglow_topks.csv')

test_batch = pd.read_csv(
    'recsys-2017-tutorial/test_batch.csv',
    header=None,
    names=['time','user','item']
)
test_relevant = test_batch[test_batch.user.isin(train_batch.user)]
test_relevant['score']=1

scores = [NdcgScore(test_relevant, topks) for topks in [alpenglow_topks, flink_topks, spark_topks]]
x=[1,2,3]
plt.bar(x, scores)
plt.title('Experiment scores')
plt.ylabel('Average NDCG')
plt.xticks(x, ['Alpenglow','Flink','Spark'])
plt.show()
